content.description: An extension of Cutting Cards for a Poke, 5.12a, which is and extension of Diving for Rocks 5.10d.  Climb cutting Cards and top out.  Fun time to do a big victory whip.
content.protection: No extra bolts above the cutting cards anchors.  just jump off onto those.  Make sure your belayer is ready.

content.description:
Tricky beta right off the ground makes for an enjoyable puzzle of a route. A fun 5.9 once you've figured out the sequence.   

  Another super polished, bouldery start with -EASY- climbing above. It's fun regardless, and it also provides convenient access to the ledge where anchors for both "Angels and Poets" and "Matter of Honor" can be accessed so you can get ready for your headpoint of these two spicy leads by practicing on top rope  :)
content.location: This is the route that people make up names for with the GIANT ARM-EATING hole at the bottom... but seriously, my wingspan is 6'8" and I cant reach the back. (Begin just left of this anomaly)

content.description:
Sometime by summer 2019, the huge tree at the right end of Seismic fell, and its absence cleared the start of an entirely different line about a yard or so right of Black Slabbath. So on July 19 I led Black Slabbath and set some directionals to facilitate TRing this "new" route.

 On September 22, I went back and led it trad. Because the placements were sketchy and there were fewer than I thought there'd be, I will not describe them or recommend gear. Basically, I led it trad just in case I really did do the FA and someone came along and said it didn't count because it was on TR.

 To anchor, I crossed over to the Black Slabbath anchors and placed a cam and a hex along the way to protect that short, easy traverse. While I have used that rock before for directionals and have rapped off such placements, that time I found that the rock there has gone from questionable to terrible, and I even trundled some large pieces. However, there is still okay rock if you look for it.

 If there is a party on BS, you will need to go up into the brush to find solid trees for anchors; the rock around the topout is not sufficient for building a safe anchor. You can TR this off the BS anchors, but a fall will mean a big swing left, possibly crashing into a climber or rope on Die Easy just  left of BS. So basically don't climb this route unless DE and BS are unoccupied or you are willing and equipped to lead the route and then crash through brush.

 My 5.6 is based on not using the fallen tree to start and on pulling onto the ledge just above where the anchors likely would be were this a sport route. Otherwise, this is maybe 5.4.

 As to the name-- there has been a recent fervor in the Austin climbing community to rename "offensive" route names. My name for the route is a poke in their collective woke eyes. And for the record, I am not a Trump voter; I just can't stand the woke/PC people.

 It will take you less time to climb this route than it took you to read about it! Enjoy!
content.protection: There is no need to bolt this route; the likely location of the anchors would make it really short, and it can be led trad or toproped off the Black Slabbath anchors with or without directionals.
content.location: Start a few feet right of the last bolted route on the right end of Seismic Wall.

climbs.name: Slimy Crack aka Icecubes, Popcorn and Popsicles

content.description:
This is the route immediately to the right of Diving for Rocks and is easily distinguished by wide-ish (fist), flaring crack.  This crack is the crux of this route - always greasy, it's tough to get your mitts to stick in this thing.   

  The top rope above this route is 12a, Lonesome Dove.
content.location: To the right of Diving for Rocks.

content.description: Tricky techniques on this short but fun route. Per the Austin climbing guidebook: "This route will make you think."  I interpret this as: "This is not 5.9", but I never really have figured out the best way to get up this thing...
content.location: On the left end of the wall, this route is immediately left of the tree.  (3rd anchor from the left end of the wall)

climbs.name: She's No Dog   She's My Wife

content.description: Solid climbing right from the start.  Stick clip the first bolt to avoid the nasty fall into the bushes.  Crux comes above the first bolt as you make a powerful move off a small right foot.  Pull some jugs to the third bolt, then find an interesting move over the bulge before finishing on a short slab to the anchor.
content.location: On the left side of Seismic.  The start is on two big holds with big feet just right of a small bush.

content.description: Super polished climbing on less than vertical rock. Great for beginners.
content.location: This route is located to the left of the tree closest to the wall on the right end.  One route to the left of Hollywood, in the less than vertical dihedral.

content.description: Crux is down low, getting on the route.  Share holds with ACK! and then it's smooth sailing to the top.  Pretty hard bottom moves for a 5.8...
content.protection: This route isn't bolted itself, but by using bolts on both ACK! and Lick the Paw one cane make it a reasonably safe lead.  Chains at the top: KNOW HOW TO CLEAN YOUR GEAR
content.location: Main Dihedral on the left side of the wall.  Between Lick the Paw and ACK!

content.description: Mantling onto the first ledge is a tough boulder problem... heel hooking, good footwork with the non-hooking foot, etc. all required to roll up onto this thing
content.location: TR From the anchor for "Rock Dog Indirect"

content.description: On the right hand side of the big roof. Work your way  up the low angle face to a big prow on the side of the roof and pull up into the honeycomb holds, then  work right along a crack to the chains. The direct start is 9+/10a and the right start maintains 5.9. Awesome route. The overhang moves are not hard, but can be scary if this is your limit.
content.location: On the right hand side of the roof formation.

content.description: Short but packing a punch, "Nose Print" is a powerful route that rarely sees any traffic.  Avoid using the crack to the right of the route or it makes it .11a
content.location: This route is to the right of She's no Dog and to the left of Rock Dog.  It has anchors beneath a prickly pear just to the left of the end of the major roof formation that covers the more popular routes on the wall.

content.description: Stout start made trickier thanks to a tree. Don't cheat! Use good feet and less than ideal hands to reach the second bolt and pull over a buldge. One more bolt on good but polished holds takes you to the chains.
content.location: The line of bolts to the right of Hollywood.  There is a tree just in front of the route (and can be used to clip the first bolt), but with a layback, you can reach that bolt without it.

climbs.name: Mister Blister
climbs.fa: David Cardosa, Scott Harris, Ralph Vega

content.description: Awkward beached whaling/ mantling/ off routing or something required to pull over the bulge.  Also, as soon as this thing gets traffic and becomes polished, it will be much harder
content.location: Immediately left of "short people" (2nd anchor from the left end of the wall)

climbs.name: Matter of Honor
climbs.fa: Ross Robertson, Ehrn Siegenthaler, Srin Surapanani, 2004

content.description: Bouldery start below first bolt.  Move through jugs over a bulge and you're at the anchors
content.protection: 3 bolts, sport anchors.  Stick clip recommended.
content.location: Left of Lick the Window.

content.description: Tricky climbing on enjoyable rock of various features.  A shame it's so short.  Called "Man Hands" because the route varies dramatically depending on finger size at the top of the route.  For some women, the route is 5.10.  For myself, however, and anyone else with man hands, it's tougher because we're unable to cram our digits into the small crack at the top.
content.protection: Bolts to a sport anchor... shared anchor for Captain Morgan
content.location: Last route in the left end of the wall.  Left of Captain Morgan

content.description: Crux is between second and third bolt where you have to commit to a small sidepull.  Above this, move though ledges and jugs to the anchors
content.location: Left of Diving for Rocks

content.description: Top rope variation from the anchors for Slimy Crack.  Slimy Crack is slimy because it used to house an enormous beehive.  Now all that is left is the beeswax funk due to... "Colony Collapse Disorder".
content.location: TR The direct line to the anchors for Slimy.  Use face holds and some crack.  Fun mantle/ heel hook/ beached whale maneuver at the bottom to begin the climb, or hike the 5.0 ledges to the left that you would use to lead slimy crack.

content.description: Tricky face climbing down low and some more enjoyable stuff up high.  Longest climb on the left end of the wall. Painful crux holds originally had this route named "Lick the Paw"  :)
content.protection: Bolts to a fixed ring anchor - know how to clean your gear!  One of the few routes on the wall without the super convenient sport anchors
content.location: One route to the right of Lick the Window.  One route left of Seismic Step.  When approaching the left side of Seismic wall this is the route that greets you at the top of the rock steps that prevent further erosion from the base of the wall.

content.description: A hard finish to Diving for Rocks
content.location: From the top of Diving for Rocks directly out the roof

content.description: Crux is low with a very fun move below the first bolt.  Fun climbing to the anchors after crux.
content.protection: 4 bolts, sport anchors.  Stick clip recommended.
content.location: First route to the left of Seismic Step, (low angle ledges) on the left half of seismic.

content.description: Just For Fun is a fun and varied line that traverses as much to the left as it does ascend vertically. Anchors near the prickly pear at the end of a short roof. Rare limestone hand jams are useful when working out the roof to get to the jugs to clip the chains.Rock Dog can be TR'ed from the anchors for this route. "Direct" also has one old bolt in it, about 20 feet up, left over from the first ascent by Tom Suhler and Bruce Becker.
content.location: To the left of Magster begins this traversing route with some interesting terrain and a fun short roof to the anchors.  This is the last route on the right end of the wall.

content.description: More polished limestone...  Again, popular with beginners. More interesting than some of the other routes adjacent to this one
content.location: One route to the right of Over Easy.

content.description: A Top Rope route rightof Hoover Head. First Lead Hoover Head, anchor in...then set up TR on anchors to the right. They are set 5' to the right of Hoover Head.
content.location: Line is to the Right of Hoover Head. You have to lead Hoover Head to set this TR.

content.description: Crux is the last move before anchors (and the moves above the anchors). Smooth crimps, then over a bulge, a few more moves to the top. Crack at the left is probably off-route, and far from bolts anyway. The last bolt is right below the anchors, skip on lead and set up a TR through it if you want.
content.protection: 3 bolts, 2 top anchors with chains (2 anchors very closeby for "Hoovering" TR)
content.location: Seismic Wall itself is across a creek (usually dry) from the main path/parking lot. Pick up "Austin Rock" (O'Grady) for nice diagrams of all Seismic routes. This route is near the left end of the wall, directly to the right of a large tree. Look for the 2 sets of anchors right next to each other ("Hoover Head" is the left route, with the bolts). Sport lead and then clean/rap down.

climbs.name: Hollywood
climbs.fa: Ralph Showalter 1999, free soloed BITD. Bolts added w/ FA permission in 2005

content.description: Great warm up climb. It starts between Roo Dog and Die Easy. Apparently used to be labeled as Rick's Way(?).

This is the longest "established" route on Seismic Wall, and it is a traverse. Because it crosses several popular lines and uses their hardware, be considerate of others and only do this route when you find this section of the wall empty. I originally listed the route as 5.8 as it is in the local guidebook, but that's a little confusing because the start is the crux and that start is also the crux of a 5.9 line. No, there's not a huge difference in those grades, but it's still a little confusing. The route has a PG rating because of the second clip and the easy runout between the third and fourth clips. The route: clip the first two bolts of the Mongrel (don't use the skinny tree if you want the 5.8 or 5.9) and then traverse left and clip Hollywood's second bolt. Traverse left and then climb Roo Dog's third and fourth bolts; climb to the anchors and clip the left anchor. Head up and left and clip Butt Scratch's left anchor. Finally, go up and left again and clip the anchors of It's a Wiggle Butt, and lower. Those anchors are easily distinguished because they are the highest on the wall.The crux is the start. The climbing on Roo Dog is 5.7/5.8, and all the rest is easy and fun.
content.protection:
5 quickdraws. You might want a couple longer slings to reduce drag, but I haven't had any real drag problems with just standard-length draws. 

  With a 40m rope, I had about 18' left over, so a 35 might just work, but a 30 will not.
content.location: The Mongrel is the third bolted route from the right end of Seismic Wall. It is between two skinny trees.

content.description: The crux is getting from the 2nd to 3rd bolt. The "easiest" way to do it is probably to lunge, but it can be done static as well. I reccommend doing it both ways for the full effect! After the crux, it is easier, but you still gotta hang on. Some of the rock up top can be a bit dusty.
content.location: Left of the climb with the greasy crack(Ice Cubes, Popcorn, and Popsicles). There may be a newer route in between them.

climbs.name: Die Easy
climbs.fa: Luke Bowman, Stefanie Petermichl and Tommy Blackwell 2006

content.description: A great warm-up or beginner route. Located just to the right of The Mongrel.
Hardest part is the end when hands get smaller and the the feet have to come over onto the fin
content.location: Route is a continuation of Diving for Rocks.  Lead out Lonesome Dove to the glue-in in the roof and then continue across on some gymnastic and powerful climbing to the anchors on the right end of the roof

content.description: Different style of climbing than most of this wall... watch out for the prickly pear cactus at the top of the route during a few traversing moves!  Some tricky moves down low before the first bolt as well.
content.protection: Bolts to a sport anchor shared with Man Hands
content.location: Second to last bolted line on the left end of the wall, right of "Man Hands" and left of "Mister Blister"

content.description: More polished climbing on uneventful terrain, also popular with beginners
content.location: Left of Roo Dog, 4th set of anchors from the right end of the wall.  Right angling, sloping ledge marks this route

content.description: Crux is at the top
content.location: First route on the far right of the wall

content.description:
Fun climbing on polished limestone.  Difficult to get off the ground, but beyond that not too much challenge.  Perhaps getting up to clip the anchors is the hardest section (assuming you clip with hands -above- the anchors) 

  Some fun TR variations exist as well, climbing left and over the bulge to the ledge below the anchors
content.location: To the right of Maggy Needs New Shoes and to the Left of Over Easy.  The anchors for this climb are the last ones located under the wall's major roof formation (right end)

climbs.name: Angel of Poets
climbs.fa: Ross Robertson, Ehrn Siegenthaler, Srin Surapanani, 2004

content.description: Thin moves below the first bolt are the crux.  Move through some jugs and you're at the anchors.
content.location: Left of Matter of Honor

content.description: Contrived start due to the proximity of the moderate dihedral to the left.  Fun pulling above that, however, on crimps and pockets past 4 total bolts.
content.location: One route to the right of the Seismic Step Dihedral.  Start standing in the bushes and make sure they're not poison ivy!

content.description: A nice wall with sport routes from 5.6 to 5.12a. Probably about 30 routes total. Faces East. Most of the routes are well shaded by trees.
